title: Radio Button - Usage Examples
description: Common usage patterns and example configurations for single-select radio button groups with vertical/horizontal layouts and custom styling

examples.name: How Did You Hear About Us? (5 Options, Vertical)
examples.description: Marketing source tracking with single-select radio buttons in vertical layout
examples.visualDescription: Five round radio buttons stacked vertically (Search Engine, Social Media, Friend Referral, Advertisement, Other), only one can be selected at a time

attributes.labelss: How did you hear about us?
attributes.error: Please select how you heard about us.

examples.useCase: Marketing attribution, lead generation forms, customer surveys, registration forms

radioButtonDetails.fldOptions: Array of radio button options - each has fldLabel (display text) and fldValue (submitted value)
radioButtonDetails.optPos: vertical - Radio buttons stack vertically (one per line)
radioButtonDetails.bRadius: round - Circular radio buttons (default for radios)
radioButtonDetails.singleSelect: Only ONE option can be selected at a time (unlike checkboxes which allow multiple)
radioButtonDetails.reqTgl: true - User must select one option (prevents empty submission)

bestPractices: Use underscore_case for fldValue (search_engine) for backend processing
Keep fldLabel descriptive (Search Engine vs just Search)
Include 'Other' option for sources not listed
Use vertical layout (optPos: vertical) for better readability with 4+ options
Set reqTgl: true for required question where user must choose one answer

examples.name: Service Rating Scale (Horizontal, 5 Levels)
examples.description: Satisfaction rating with 5 levels from Poor to Excellent in horizontal layout
examples.visualDescription: Five round radio buttons in horizontal row (Poor, Fair, Good, Very Good, Excellent), help text below explains to select one option

attributes.labelss: How would you rate our service?
attributes.desctxt: Please select one rating that best describes your experience.

examples.useCase: Customer satisfaction surveys, product reviews, service feedback, post-purchase ratings

ratingScalePattern.fldValue: Use numeric values (1-5) for easy backend scoring/averaging
ratingScalePattern.fldLabel: Use descriptive words (Poor, Fair, Good, Very Good, Excellent)
ratingScalePattern.order: Low to high (Poor → Excellent) or high to low based on preference
ratingScalePattern.optPos: horizontal - Works well for rating scales (users familiar with left-to-right progression)
ratingScalePattern.help: Explain that user should select ONE rating that best fits their experience

layoutDetails.optPos: horizontal - Radio buttons display in a row (side by side)
layoutDetails.bRadius: round - Circular radio buttons (traditional radio style)
layoutDetails.hlpTxt: true - Show help text to explain rating selection
layoutDetails.descPoss: bottom - Help text appears below radio buttons

warnings: Horizontal layout works best with 3-6 options (too many wraps awkwardly on mobile)
On mobile, horizontal radio buttons may stack vertically automatically (depends on label length)
Ensure adequate spacing between radio buttons in horizontal layout for touch targets

examples.name: Yes/No Question (Binary Choice, Horizontal, Square Style)
examples.description: Simple binary choice with square-styled radio buttons
examples.visualDescription: Two square radio buttons in horizontal row (Yes, No), square styling instead of traditional circular

attributes.labelss: Would you recommend us to a friend?
attributes.error: Please indicate whether you would recommend us.

examples.useCase: NPS (Net Promoter Score) surveys, binary questions, yes/no decisions, recommendation tracking

binaryChoicePattern.optPos: horizontal - Compact side-by-side layout for binary choices
binaryChoicePattern.bRadius: square - Alternative styling (round is default, square for variation)

squareRadioStyle.bRadius: square - Square corners instead of circular (visual variation)
squareRadioStyle.when: Use for binary choices, modern designs, or to match form aesthetics
squareRadioStyle.default: Radio buttons default to round (circular) - square is optional override

npsContext.useCase: Net Promoter Score (NPS) surveys often use Yes/No for recommendation
npsContext.followUp: Pair with nxt-number-field (0-10 rating) or nxt-message-field (reason)
npsContext.calculation: Yes = Promoter, No = Detractor (for NPS scoring)

examples.name: Gender Selection (Demographic, 3 Options)
examples.description: Standard demographic gender question with inclusive options
examples.visualDescription: Three round radio buttons stacked vertically (Male, Female, Prefer not to say), required field
examples.useCase: Demographics forms, user profiles, registration, surveys, health forms

demographicGuidelines.inclusive: Always include 'Prefer not to say' option for privacy
demographicGuidelines.modern: Consider adding 'Non-binary' or 'Other' for inclusive forms
demographicGuidelines.optional: Consider making gender optional (reqTgl: false) unless truly necessary
demographicGuidelines.privacy: Explain why gender data is collected (help text)

warnings: Gender questions can be sensitive - consider making optional (reqTgl: false)
For inclusive forms, add 'Non-binary', 'Other', or 'Prefer to self-describe' options
Some jurisdictions have legal requirements for inclusive gender options
Always include 'Prefer not to say' for user privacy

examples.name: Shipping Method (E-Commerce, Pricing Display)
examples.description: Shipping options with speed and pricing information in labels
examples.visualDescription: Three radio buttons showing shipping methods with prices (Standard $5 - 5-7 days, Express $15 - 2-3 days, Overnight $25 - Next day), vertical layout

attributes.desctxt: Estimated delivery times may vary based on destination.
attributes.error: Please select a shipping method to continue.

examples.useCase: E-commerce checkout, shipping selection, delivery options, order forms

pricingDisplayPattern.fldLabel: Include price and timeframe in label (Standard Shipping - $5.00 - 5-7 days)
pricingDisplayPattern.fldValue: Encode price in value (standard_5) for backend calculation
pricingDisplayPattern.calculation: Backend extracts price from fldValue (standard_5 → $5) and adds to order total

implementationNotes.total: Order total = product price + shipping cost
implementationNotes.display: Show selected shipping option and cost in order summary

examples.name: Payment Method (Icons Recommended, 3 Options)
examples.description: Payment method selection with descriptive labels for Credit Card, PayPal, Bank Transfer
examples.visualDescription: Three round radio buttons (Credit/Debit Card, PayPal, Bank Transfer), vertical layout, help text explains processing

fldOptions.fldLabel: Credit or Debit Card (Visa, Mastercard, Amex)

attributes.desctxt: All payment methods are secure and encrypted.

examples.useCase: E-commerce checkout, donation forms, subscription payments, invoice payments

paymentMethodPattern.labels: Include accepted card types or details (Visa, Mastercard, Amex)
paymentMethodPattern.values: Use standard payment method codes (credit_card, paypal, bank_transfer)
paymentMethodPattern.security: Add help text about encryption/security to build trust
paymentMethodPattern.icons: Consider adding payment icons (Visa/MC logos) - requires custom implementation

warnings: Radio button block doesn't support icons natively - use custom CSS or HTML in fldLabel
For actual payment processing, use dedicated payment gateway (Stripe, PayPal, etc.)
Selected payment method should trigger appropriate payment form fields (card number, PayPal email, etc.)
Consider using payment gateway's hosted fields for PCI compliance

conditionalFields.credit_card: Show: Card Number, Expiry Date, CVV, Cardholder Name fields
conditionalFields.paypal: Show: PayPal email or redirect to PayPal checkout
conditionalFields.bank_transfer: Show: Account Number, Routing Number, Account Holder Name fields

examples.name: T-Shirt Size (Horizontal, 6 Options)
examples.description: Apparel size selection in horizontal layout from XS to XXL
examples.visualDescription: Six round radio buttons in horizontal row (XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL), compact design for size selection
examples.useCase: E-commerce apparel, event registration with shirt giveaway, merchandise orders, uniform selection

sizeSelectionPattern.abbreviations: Use standard abbreviations (XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL) for compact horizontal layout
sizeSelectionPattern.order: Smallest to largest (XS → XXL) for intuitive left-to-right progression
sizeSelectionPattern.optPos: horizontal - Works well for size scales (users expect left-to-right sizing)
sizeSelectionPattern.helpText: Link to size chart for measurements (desctxt: 'See size chart')

warnings: Six horizontal radio buttons may wrap on small mobile screens (test on actual devices)
Consider using short labels (XS, S, M) instead of full names (Extra Small, Small, Medium)
International sizing differs (US vs EU vs UK) - specify sizing standard
For unisex items, consider separate Men's/Women's size options

internationalSizing.US: XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL

validationRules.labelss: Required string - Field label/heading for radio button group
validationRules.fldOptions: Required array - List of radio button options (minimum 2 for meaningful choice)
validationRules.fldOptions[].fldLabel: Required string - Display text shown to user
validationRules.fldOptions[].fldValue: Required string - Value submitted to backend (use lowercase, underscores)
validationRules.reqTgl: Boolean - true requires one option selected, false makes selection optional
validationRules.uniqueid: String - Unique form field identifier for submission data

warnings: Radio buttons allow selecting ONLY ONE option (unlike checkboxes which allow multiple)
reqTgl: true validates that exactly ONE option is selected (prevents empty submission)
No way to set default selected option in block.json - requires JavaScript or backend pre-selection
Once user selects a radio button, they cannot 'unselect' all - there's always one selected
Horizontal layout (optPos: horizontal) can wrap awkwardly with 6+ options on mobile
bRadius only affects visual styling (round vs square), not functionality
Long fldLabel text in horizontal layout causes wrapping - keep labels concise (1-3 words)
Radio button value is submitted as string, not array (unlike checkboxes)
For 'Other' option with free text input, pair with nxt-message-field using conditional logic
Once a radio is selected, user cannot deselect all options - ensure 'N/A' or 'None' option if needed
commonMistakes: Using radio buttons for multi-select (use nxt-checkbox-button instead)
Using horizontal layout with 10+ options (wraps poorly on mobile)
Using spaces or special characters in fldValue (use underscores: 'search_engine' not 'Search Engine')
Not providing 'Other' or 'None of the above' option when appropriate
Making radio buttons optional when user should provide an answer (set reqTgl: true)
Using generic fldValue like 'option1' instead of descriptive 'search_engine'
Not testing mobile layout for horizontal radio buttons (may need vertical on small screens)
Including prices in fldValue instead of fldLabel (put '$5' in label, 'standard_5' in value)
Forgetting that radio selections cannot be unselected (always one selected after first click)
Using radio buttons for single Yes/No when checkbox might be clearer
bestPractices: Use descriptive fldValue names (search_engine, credit_card) not generic (option1, option2)
Keep fldValue lowercase with underscores for consistent backend processing
Use vertical layout (optPos: vertical) for 4+ options for better readability
Use horizontal layout (optPos: horizontal) only for 2-6 short options (Yes/No, sizes, ratings)
Set reqTgl: true when user must choose one answer (prevent empty submission)
Set reqTgl: false only when selection is truly optional (rare for radio buttons)
Provide 'Other', 'None of the above', or 'N/A' option when appropriate
Use help text (hlpTxt + desctxt) to clarify what the selection means or affects
Include pricing/timeframes in fldLabel for e-commerce options (Standard $5 - 5-7 days)
Use numeric values (1-5) for rating scales to simplify backend averaging
For binary choices (Yes/No), consider horizontal layout for compact display
Use round bRadius for traditional radio appearance, square for modern/alternative styling
Test horizontal layouts on mobile - 6+ options likely need vertical on small screens
Use uniqueid that describes the field purpose ('shipping_method', 'payment_method')
For 'Other' option, pair with conditional nxt-message-field for user explanation
accessibilityNotes: Label (labelss) is required for screen readers to identify radio button group purpose
Each fldLabel is announced individually by screen readers as radio button label
Use descriptive fldLabel text: 'Search Engine (Google, Bing)' not just 'Search'
Help text (desctxt) provides additional context for assistive technology
Error messages (error attribute) are announced by screen readers when validation fails
Radio buttons are keyboard accessible (Tab to navigate, Arrow keys to select within group)
Ensure sufficient color contrast for radio button borders (minimum 3:1 ratio)
Don't rely on color alone to indicate selected state (use filled circle/check icon)
Group related radio buttons under clear heading (labelss) for screen reader navigation
Large touch targets on mobile (minimum 44x44px) - TPGB default styling handles this
Arrow keys should work within radio group (↑↓ for vertical, ←→ for horizontal)
performanceConsiderations: Browser native radio button rendering is instant (no custom JavaScript needed)
Large number of radio buttons (20+) may slow down form rendering - consider nxt-option-field (dropdown) instead
Radio button validation happens on submit, not on every selection
Vertical layout performs better on mobile than horizontal (no wrapping calculations)
If using dynamic radio buttons, debounce selection logic to avoid excessive re-renders

vertical.bestFor: 4+ options, long labels, default choice for most forms
vertical.spacing: Each radio button on separate line for easy scanning
vertical.mobile: Works perfectly on mobile (no wrapping issues)

horizontal.bestFor: 2-6 options, short labels (1-3 words), rating scales, binary choices
horizontal.spacing: Radio buttons in a row, may wrap on mobile if too many
horizontal.mobile: Test carefully - long labels cause wrapping, consider vertical for mobile

nxt-radio-button.selection: SINGLE-select only (one option at a time)
nxt-radio-button.unselect: Cannot unselect all after first selection
nxt-radio-button.useCase: Mutually exclusive choices (shipping method, payment method, gender, rating)
nxt-radio-button.validation: reqTgl ensures exactly ONE option selected

nxt-checkbox-button.unselect: Can uncheck all options (empty selection possible)
nxt-checkbox-button.useCase: Multiple selections allowed (skills, interests, preferences, features)
nxt-checkbox-button.validation: reqTgl ensures at least ONE checkbox checked

whenToUse.radio: User picks ONE from several options (Which method? Select shipping. Choose size.)
whenToUse.checkbox: User picks MULTIPLE from several options (What skills? Select interests. Choose features.)
